title-group.article-title: Screening of immunomodulatory activity of total and protein extracts of some Moroccan medicinal plants

article-meta.aff: 1Bioactive Molecules Laboratory, Immunology and Pharmacology Unit, Faculty of Science and Technology, Fez, Morocco
2Department of Natural Products and Alternative Medicine, Faculty of Pharmacy, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
3Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Essam Abdel-Sattar, Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Cairo University, El-Kasr El-Aini Street, Cairo 11562, Egypt. Email: abdelsattar@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Herbal and traditional medicines are being widely used in practice in many countries for their benefits of treating different ailments. A large number of plants in Morocco were used in folk medicine to treat immune-related disorders. The objective of this study is to evaluate the immunomodulatory activity of protein extracts (PEs) of 14 Moroccan medicinal plants. This activity was tested on the proliferation of immune cells. The prepared total and PEs of the plant samples were tested using MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay on the splenocytes with or without stimulation by concanavalin-A (Con-A), a mitogenic agent used as positive control. The results of this study indicated different activity spectra. Three groups of activities were observed. The first group represented by Citrullus colocynthis, Urtica dioica, Elettaria cardamomum, Capparis spinosa and Piper cubeba showed a significant immunosuppressive activity. The second group that showed a significant immunostimulatory activity was represented by Aristolochia longa, Datura stramonium, Marrubium vulgare, Sinapis nigra, Delphynium staphysagria, Lepidium sativum, Ammi visnaga and Tetraclinis articulata. The rest of the plant extracts did not alter the proliferation induced by Con-A. This result was more important for the PE than for the total extract. In conclusion, this study revealed an interesting immunomodulating action of certain PEs, which could explain their traditional use. The results of this study may also have implications in therapeutic treatment of infections, such as prophylactic and adjuvant with cancer chemotherapy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The ethnopharmacological knowledge is helpful in the search of plants with potential biological activity. Many medicinal plants have been used for the treatment of several diseases by Moroccan population. The activity of the plants with therapeutic potential may be mediated by the interaction with the host’s immune system (Franz, 1989; Wagner, 1990), resulting in immunomodulatory effect.

In traditional Moroccan medicine, plants under investigation were used to treat several diseases (Bellakhdar, 1997; Hmamouchi, 1999). Scientific reports have shown several actions for plants selected, but few of them were indicated as immunomodulating agents, namely, Citrullus colocynthis L., (Bendjeddou et al., 2003), Urtica dioïca L., (Harput et al., 2005) Capparis spinosa L. (Arena et al., 2008) and Elettaria cardamomum L., (Majdalawieh and Carr, 2010).

In this work, our objective is to evaluate the immune activity of a group of plants, such as C. colocynthis, E. cardamomum, Piper cubeba, Ammi visnaga, U. dioica, Juncus acuntis, C. spinosa, Aristolochia longa, Marrubium vulgare, Delphynium staphysagria, Sinapis nigra, Tetraclinis articulate, Lepidium sativum and D. stramonium, used in traditional medicine against immune disorders.

sec.title: Chemicals and reagents
sec.p: Chemicals were purchased from Sigma (St. Louis, MO, USA). Concanavalin-A (Con-A) was dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 1 mg/mL) and used at a final concentration of 7 µg/mL. MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) was dissolved in PBS at 5 mg/mL. Roswell Park Memorial Institute 1640 (RMPI 1641) medium (without glucose) was supplemented with 1 mM sodium pyruvate.

sec.title: Plants materials
sec.p: Plants under investigation were selected based on ethnobotanical information from Moroccan traditional medicine. The plants were collected from Fez Boulmane region (Morocco), except for P. cubeba, which was purchased from local herbal store. Voucher specimens were deposited in the herbarium Laboratory of Bioactive Molecules, Faculty of Sciences and Techniques, Saïs, Morocco.

sec.title: Extraction
sec.p: The total extracts (TEs) of different plants were prepared separately by extraction with PBS. Ten gram of each plant powder (Table 1) was extracted with 100 mL of PBS by stirring for 2 hours at room temperature. The suspension was centrifuged (15 min at 4500 rpm at 4°C), and the supernatant was sterilized by filtration through 0.22 µm nitrocellulose filters.

caption.p: Ethnobotanical data of medicinal plants used.

tr.td: Asthma, toothpick, diabetes and skin diseases.
Merzouki et al., 2000; Jouad et al., 2002; Khan et al., 2001.
Cutaneous neoplasm, cancer, anti-inflammatory and also used as antiseptic.
Migraine, diarrhea, skin diseases, cancer and also used as antioxidant and sexual stimulant.
Stüven and Pflugmacher 2007; Aburjai et al., 2001.
Bronchitis, constipation, rheumatism and bladder diseases.
Rheumatism, inflammatory arthritis and also used as antifungal, hypolipidemic, antiviral and immunomodulatory.
Trombetta et al., 2005; Al-said et al., 1988; Ageel et al., 1986; Eddouks et al., 2005; Arena, 2008.
Hypertension, diabetes, rheumatic tuberculosis, syphilis, spasmolytic inflammatory and also used as antifungal, antibacterial, antioxidant, analgesic and immunostimulatory.
Ziyyat et al., 1997; Bendjeddou et al., 2003; Gebhardt, 2003; Merzouki et al., 2000; Marzouk et al., 2010; Hadizadeh et al., 2009.
Asthma, diabetes, hypertension and also used for hair tonics.
Bellakhdar et al., 1991; Merzouki et al., 2000; Ziyyat et al., 1997.
Kidney stones, inflammatory and skin diseases.
DellaGreca et al., 2002; Merzouki et al., 2000.
Bilious and also used as antibacterial, analgesic and hair tonics.
Meyre-Silva et al., 2005; Abakri and Afifi, 2007; Román Ramos et al., 1992.
Rheumatic, diarrhoeic, inflammatory and also used as sexual stimulant, antiseptic and antimicrobial.
Choi and Hwang, 2003; Elfahmi et al., 2007; Silva et al., 2007.
Toothache and also used as hair tonics and anti-louse.
Asthmatic and sedative and also used as antimicrobial narcotic.
Pretorius and Marx, 2006; Eftekhar et al., 2005.
Kidney infections, cancer and inflammatory and also used as antioxidant, antifungal, antimicrobial immunomodulatory.
Ziyyat et al., 1997; Konrad et al., 2000; Franz, 1989; Safarinejad, 2005; Gülçin et al., 2004; Harput et al., 2005; Hadizadeh et al., 2009.

sec.p: The protein extract (PE) was prepared from the TE by precipitation of protein by addition of cold ammonium sulfate (44%) at 4°C (England and Seifter, 1990). Addition of ammonium sulfate is followed by a gentle stirring of the solution and then the samples were centrifuged at 10,000 rpm at 4°C for 10 min. The supernatant was removed and the pellet and was resuspended in PBS followed by desalting and concentration with polyethylene glycol 6000. The recovered dialysates were then divided and frozen at −20°C for later use. In this study, we have used 0.1 mg/mL PBS of TE and 0.1 mg/mL PBS of PE as final concentration for all plants.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: For isolation of splenocytes, the animals were raised, housed and maintained with a standard diet in an air conditioned and clean room. All experimental procedures involving the handling and caring of animals were conducted in conformity with ethical guidelines.

sec.title: In vitro immunomodulatory assay
sec.p: The splenocytes were isolated as described by Chandrashekar and Venkatesh, (2009). The suspended cells were washed after centrifugation repeatedly in RPMI medium and the red blood cells were lysed by 154 mM ammonium chloride. The density of cell suspension cultures was determined microscopically by trypan blue exclusion test. The culture was performed in RPMI culture medium (without glucose) supplemented with 2 mM glutamine, 1 mM sodium pyruvate, 10% fetal calf serum, ampicillin 100 U/mL and streptomycin 100 µg/mL.

The mitogenic activity of plant samples was followed by MTT assay. The splenocytes were planted at a concentration of 5000 cells/100 µL/well in 96-well plates and incubated at 37°C in humidified chamber under an atmosphere of 95% air and 5% CO2 for 24 hours. The plates were further incubated for 48 hours after stimulation by addition of 10 µL of mitogenic agent Con-A (7 µg/mL in PBS) and treated with 10 µL of TE or PE. Thereafter, 10 µL of MTT (5 mg/mL in PBS) was added and incubated for 3 hours at 37°C (Mosmann et al., 1983). At the end, the supernatant was removed and replaced by 100 µL of dimethyl sufoxide. The coloration obtained after 1 hour was measured at a wavelength of 570 nm. Splenocytes stimulated by Con-A in the absence of TE or PE represent the control groups.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Each experimental condition was realized, at least, in duplicate (n = 2). All the data obtained from “N” experiments during the investigation are expressed as mean ± standard error. Student’s t test was used to compare the difference between treated and control groups (Sokal and Rohlf, 1995). Differences were considered statistically significant for p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Assessment of immunomodulatory activity of TE and PE of the 14 plants was carried out at a dosage of 0.1 mg/mL PBS. The splenocytes were cultured in RPMI stimulated or not by the mitogenic agent Con-A (7 µg/mL PBS) for 72 hours at 37°C. The effect of plant extracts on the cells was measured by MTT assay.

Cytotoxicity effect was verified by comparing the cells treated by the TE or the PE on the cells alone, in which the extracts were added during the incubation period. All the tested extracts (TE and PE) did not inhibit cell proliferation (Tables 2 and 3), except TE of C. colocynthis, which showed a slight cytotoxicity of 83.07% relative to the cell proliferation alone (N = 5).

caption.p: Effect of plant total extracts on the proliferation of splenocytes stimulated by Con-A.

tr.th: Percentage of proliferation in the presence of TE

fn.p: Con-A: concanavalin-A (7 µg/mL PBS); TE: total extracts (0.1 mg/mL PBS); OD: optical density; PBS: phosphate-buffered saline; Ci co: Citrullus colocynthis; Pi cu: Piper cubeba; El ca: Elettaria cardamomum; Ma vu: Marrubium vulgare; Am vi: Ammi visnaga; Ar lo: Aristolochia longa; Te ar: Tetraclinis articulata; Ju ac: Juncus acutus; Ur di: Urtica dioica; Si ni: Sinapis nigra; Ca sp: Capparis spinosa; De st: Delphinium staphysagria; Da st: Datura stramonium; Le sa: Lepidium sativum.
aPercentage obtained by the following formula: OD (cells + TE) × 100/OD (cells alone).
bPercentage obtained by the following formula: OD (Cells + Con-A + TE) × 100/DO (Cells + Con-A).
c Student’s test: t–test: inhibition of proliferation; +: stimulation of proliferation, 0: no effect.

caption.p: Effect of plant protein extracts on the proliferation of splenocytes stimulated by Con-A.

tr.th: Percentage of proliferation in the presence of PE

fn.p: Con-A: concanavalin-A (7 µg/mL PBS); PE: protein extracts (0.1 mg/mL PBS); OD: optical density; PBS: phosphate-buffered saline; Ci co: Citrullus colocynthis; Pi cu: Piper cubeba; El ca: Elettaria cardamomum; Ma vu: Marrubium vulgare; Am vi: Ammi visnaga; Ar lo: Aristolochia longa; Te ar: Tetraclinis articulata; Ju ac: Juncus acutus; Ur di: Urtica dioica; Si ni: Sinapis nigra; Ca sp: Capparis spinosa; De st: Delphinium staphysagria; Da st: Datura stramonium; Le sa: Lepidium sativum.
aPercentage obtained by the following formula: OD (cells + PE) × 100/OD (cells alone).
bPercentage obtained by the following formula: OD (cells + Con-A + PE) × 100/OD (cells + Con-A).
c Student’s test: t–test: inhibition of proliferation; +: stimulation of proliferation; 0: no effect.

sec.p: Immunomodulatory effect of TE and PE on the other hand was assessed in the following manner. In the experimental series, Con-A induced an increase in the cell proliferation varying from 130% to 167.5% of control response. The comparison of the proliferation effects of tested TE and PE relative to the mitogenic effect of Con-A can be categorized into three groups of plants.
For the TE, the results presented in Table 2 and Figure 1 (N = 5) allowed us to deduce these three groups of plants.

caption.p: Effects of plant total extracts (TEs; 0.1 mg/mL PBS) on the proliferation of splenocytes. The effect of extract was determined by comparing tested extract to the positive control mitogen Con-A in the absence and in the presence of TE. Results are expressed as mean OD ± SE from independent experiments tests (N = 5). The significance was evaluated by means of Student’s t test. Con-A: concanavalin-A; OD: optical density; SE: standard error; PBS: phosphate-buffered saline.

list-item.p: Plants of group A1: This group reduced the cell proliferation induced by Con-A from 76.1% to 94.2%. This group includes C. colocynthis, U. dioica E. cardamomum, C. spinosa and P. cubeba; this effect was significantly different from the control at p < 0.05 (Student’s t test) for C. colocynthis.
Plants of group B1: The plants of this group did not modify Con-A proliferation, except for J. acuntis.

Plants of group C1: The plants of this group showed a significant difference at p < 0.05 (Student’s t test) to increase the cell proliferation, compared with the control induced by Con-A, from 136% to 292%. This group includes A. longa, D. stramonium, M. vulgare, S. nigra, D. staphysagria, L. sativum, A. visnaga and T. articulata.

sec.p: For the PE, the results presented in Table 3 and Figure 2 (N = 5) allowed us to deduce three groups of plants, but they have more immunomodulatory effect than the TE.

caption.p: Effects of plant protein extracts (PEs; 0.1 mg/mL PBS) on the proliferation of splenocytes. The effect of extract was determined by comparing tested extract to the positive control mitogen Con-A in the absence and in the presence of PE. Results are expressed as mean OD ± SE from independent experiments tests (N = 5). The significance was evaluated by means of Student’s t test. Con-A: concanavalin-A; OD: optical density; SE: standard error; PBS: phosphate-buffered saline.

list-item.p: Plants of group A2: In this group, the effect of the PE reduced the mitogenic effect of Con-A. This group includes C. colocynthis, P. cubeba, M. vulgare, A. visnaga, E. cardamomum and A. longa. The effect was significant for C. colocynthis (58.8%) and P. cubeba (72.9%).
Plants of group B2: In this group, the effect of the PE was equal to that of Con-A. This group includes J. acuntis, T. articulata, S. nigra, U. dioica and C. spinosa.

Plants of group C2: This group includes D. Staphysagria, D. stramonium and L. sativum, with a proliferative effect superior to the mitogenic effect of Con-A, with significant effects for the last two plants of 236% and 296%, respectively.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we evaluated the immunomodulatory activity of 14 plants used for improving the immune system function in traditional Moroccan medicine. The choice of plants and their parts used was based on their uses by Moroccan population or their referential therapeutic indications (Table 1).

The TE and PE of these plants were tested on the proliferation of splenocytes. The optimal cell density at 5000 cells/100 µL for 72 hours incubation was determined by exclusion test using trypan blue method. The optimal dose of the standard mitogen Con-A used in this study was 7 µg/mL, which corresponds to 48.8% averaged equivalent to that used in other studies (Amirghofran et al., 2000; Sodhi and Kesherwani, 2007). Colorimetric MTT assay was used to assess splenocyte proliferation, since the cleavage of MTT has several desirable properties for assaying cell survival and proliferation. MTT is metabolized by living cells and the amount of MTT formazan generated is directly proportional to the number of cells (Mosmann, 1983).

The design of the study includes evaluation of the effect of TE and PE on the proliferation of splenocyte alone, which showed no cytotoxic effect at the dose used except for TE of C. colocynthis, which induces a slight decrease at 16.9% in cell proliferation. It has been shown earlier that C. colocynthis extract in the range of 25–100 μg/mL over an incubation time of 22 hours did not alter the measured viability parameters in liver slices, but there is only a tendency to cytochrome P450 inhibition (Barth et al., 2002). This result is in agreement with our findings, since we observed a slight decrease at 10-fold higher concentration. Furthermore, we investigated the immunomodulatory activity of plant TE and PE by comparing the activity in the presence of the mitogenic agent Con-A, relative to the effect of Con-A alone. The results presented in Tables 2 and 3 and Figures 1 and 2 showed decrease in the proliferation of splenocytes to 76.1% for TE of C. colocynthis and to 58.8% and 72.9% for the PE of C. colocynthis and P. cubeba, respectively. These values were significantly different from the control at p < 0.05 (Student’s t test).

Bendjeddou and his colleagues (2003) obtained similar results in the immunosuppressive effect produced on mice by C. colocynthis after its oral administration at a dosage of 25–100 mg/kg/day (Bendjeddou et al., 2003). These findings may confirm the immunosuppressive activity of C. colocynthis. Similarly, other studies have confirmed the immunomodulating activities of several plants against the immunosuppression effect of cyclophosphamide in mice (Ghonime et al., 2010), such as the stimulation effect observed on the administration of the ethanolic extract of flowers of Woodfordia fruticosa (Shah and Juvekar, 2010).

Mitogenic activity was described in this study; the TE showed significant response for eight plants including A. longa, M. vulgare, Delphinium staphisagria, A. visnaga, S. nigra, T. articulata, D. stramonium and L. sativum. Moreover, the PE showed a highly significant effect on the control at p < 0.05 (Student’s t test) for D. stramonium and L. sativum, with 236% and 296%, respectively.

Previous studies described the same mitogenic effect for L. sativum, which contains a lectin glycoprotein (Ziska et al., 1982), and the PE of D. stramonium seed, which contains D. stramonium lectin (DSL) (Crowley et al., 1984; Kennedy et al., 1995). Therefore, the proliferative activity of D. stramonium, previously reported on the proliferation of human lymphocytes, could be attributed to the content of DSL (McCurrach and Kilpatrick, 1988). In contrast to the PE of U. dioica, which has no mitogenic activity in contrary to the other studies, the existence of lectin was indicated in the U. dioica with specific T cell mitogenic action (Galelli and Truffa-Bachi, 1993). The PE of C. colocynthis, D. stramonium and L. sativum have immunomodulatory activity due to the presence of lectins (Hajto et al., 1989), proteins, peptides (Kuttan and Kuttan, 1992) and polysaccharides (Angone et al., 2010).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study explains the popularity of the Moroccan plants in folk medicine. The results obtained in this study taken together with reports of other publications have shown functional activities of these plant extracts. This study also provided a view of the importance of immunomodulatory PEs of certain plants. It is interesting to note the importance of immunosuppression of the PE of C. colocynthis, a finding that could be a basis for its use in immune dysfunction (transplant grafts, autoimmune diseases, cancer, etc.). Further study is in progress to evaluate the mechanism of immune action, isolate, and to characterize the immunomodulatory protein factors from C. colocynthis is in progress.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
